title: Snow Dome (Canada)
text:
Snow Dome is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> located on the <a href="Continental%20Divide%20of%20the%20Americas">Continental Divide</a> in the <a href="Columbia%20Icefield">Columbia Icefield</a>, where the boundary of <a href="Banff%20National%20Park">Banff National Park</a> and <a href="Jasper%20National%20Park">Jasper National Park</a> meets the border of <a href="Alberta">Alberta</a> and <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a> in <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. The summit's elevation is .
The mountain was named in 1898 by J. Norman Collie because its permanently snow and ice-capped <a href="massif">massif</a> resembles a dome.
The mountain is one of two hydrological apexes of North America; it is a major <a href="triple%20divide">triple divide</a> between three great <a href="drainage%20basin">drainage basin</a>s. Water falling on Snow Dome's summit may flow into streams that drain into the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> (via the <a href="Bush%20River%20%28British%20Columbia%29">Bush River</a> and the <a href="Columbia%20River">Columbia River</a>), the <a href="Arctic%20Ocean">Arctic Ocean</a> (via the <a href="Athabasca%20River">Athabasca River</a>), and <a href="Hudson%20Bay">Hudson Bay</a> (via the <a href="North%20Saskatchewan%20River">North Saskatchewan River</a>). The "Dome Glacier" flows to the north-east, the "Stutfield Glacier" to the north-west, the "Columbia Glacier" to the west and <a href="Athabasca%20Glacier">Athabasca Glacier</a> flows to the east of the mountain. The other apex is <a href="Triple%20Divide%20Peak%20%28Montana%29">Triple Divide Peak</a> in <a href="Glacier%20National%20Park%20%28U.S.%29">Glacier National Park</a>, <a href="Montana">Montana</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
